message: This morning, we started our first official day at a congressional prayer service hosted by House leadership.  We were reminded of the call to be servant leaders, and to put others before ourselves, our goals and our ambitions.  The message was very clear to me, whether it was from the Gospel of Matthew, the Old Testament, or from our Hindu or Buddhist colleagues - we in congress are Called to serve, not be served.  I ask for your prayers as we begin this journey!
It is official! I am proud to be the Congressman of Kansas' 1st Congressional District. Thanks to the many of you who have supported my family and I through this process.   Time to get to work.

Check out this story from KWCH 12 Eyewitness News on the priorities of the 115th Congress. We have a lot of work ahead of us, but as a member of the "Doc Caucus," I look forward to being a leading voice on healthcare issues.
Read my op-ed in the Salina Journal. You have long demanded change in our bureaucratic regulatory process. This week, we started to deliver on that demand, and put "REINS" on the Executive Branch.

It was my honor this morning to talk with General Joseph Dunford, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He spoke to a bipartisan group of freshmen Members of Congress. Also pictured is Congresswoman Lisa Blunt Rochester.  We discussed the competitive advantage the US military has over our adversaries, and the reality that this advantage is eroding. General Dunford acknowledged these challenges, but reminded us that the quality of our military is A+.  He discussed many issues with us, the most pressing of which is our need for a coordinated effort to fight radical Islamic terror, and about the dawning of the age of cyber warfare.  We also discussed the various state actors around the world. We talked about the military and intelligence operations being built in Russia as they also try to undermine our credibility in NATO.  General Dunford also talked about China, North Korea, and the various challenges those countries are causing diplomatically.  The Chairman stressed the importance of a long-term bipartisan plan to give consistency, investment and strength to our armed forces and their leadership. I look forward to working with my colleagues to provide that plan.

Today, we recognize National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. I have joined several of my colleagues in signing a letter to the President recognizing the day, as well as placing blue lights in our office windows.  As the son of a Chief of Police, I have lived my whole life respecting the men and women who put their lives on the line for our public order and safety.   Last year, around 140 officers were killed in the line of duty. The least we can do is honor their memory, thank the officers who serve daily, and recognize those who have served.

Just wrapped up breakfast with other physicians in Congress, and former Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich. It was great to hear his take on solving the many healthcare problems we face! We remain committed to improving our healthcare system in the coming Congress.

This afternoon, in the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology meeting, I questioned the EPA’s interpretation of the Waters of the United States Act (WOTUS). His answer solidified farmers' concerns stating WOTUS overreach was “inappropriate and probably illegal.” I was glad to have the opportunity to bring this concern to the hearing, and will continue the due diligence that is needed to protect our farmers back home.

Grateful for the members of the Kansas National Guard who responded to the dangerous wildfires that overtook more than 1,000 square miles of our state last month.   Capt. Casey Atkins, operations officer AASF #2, pilot in command of UH-60 Black Hawk Helicopter (pictured), was part of the first-ever domestic air mission for the U.S. Army Reserve under the Immediate Response Authority, which allows local authorities to take action to save lives and mitigate property damages in situations of extreme emergency.   In all, seven Kansas Army National Guard helicopters dropped a combined total of 482 buckets of water, which equates to roughly 289,200 gallons of water. This effort, in combination with local responders on the ground, was instrumental in stopping the spread of the fires.  I am thankful for Capt. Atkins and all of the National Guard personnel who responded to the historic fires and kept our residents safe.

I want to congratulate Sonny Perdue on his long-overdue confirmation to Secretary of the US Department of Agriculture. His leadership is especially relevant as producers face record world surpluses and depressed farm prices.  Throughout this long process, one silver lining has been the broad, bipartisan support shown for Perdue, and support coming from all over the ag community. It shows that agriculture can still put partisanship aside for the good of our country, economy and our producers. I welcome the chance to work hand-in-hand with the Secretary as we help producers navigate existing programs and as we look toward the 2018 farm bill.  In addition to farm and nutrition policy, I expect Perdue to be a sound champion for trade, something I have heard time and again from Kansans concerned about our ability to open new markets for products made in Kansas. Secretary Perdue's experience as an exporter and governor leading trade missions will be invaluable as this administration pursues trade policy.  As I have said before, Perdue’s background growing up on a farm, his service in the military as a veterinarian, as well as his career in agribusiness and successful tenure as governor, make him a good fit to lead the US Department of Agriculture at this critical time for our nation’s farmers and ranchers.

Regarding my vote against the omnibus appropriations bill:  I cannot, in good conscience, vote for an appropriations measure that makes no attempt at deficit reduction and, in fact, increases overall spending. As Republicans, we have to do better than this.  While I commend and agree with House Leadership’s increased investment in our military, we simply cannot ignore yet another missed opportunity to cut federal spending. The scene of tornado damage was all too familiar to my eyes as I visited impacted areas this morning.   Having raced over to Hoisington shortly after its devastating destruction in 2001, and having witnessed firsthand a tornado go through our hunting cabin and hunting land and surrounding neighbors (the same tornado that destroyed Greensburg), this scene of leafless trees and flattened houses brought back to reality how helpless we all are in the face of Mother Nature.   According to Barton County Sheriff Bellendir, who has kept me updated, some 15 houses were left with only a foundation. One minor injury was treated on the scene.  Since the tornado, we've had several early evening storms, several of which contained 60 -70 mile an hour winds, hail, and sheets of ice like I've never seen before.  It would appear that some people will have excellent wheat crops this year, and others will have none.  As we have now suffered over the past 2 months with a 600,000-acre prairie fire, a 15-20" snow in May, tornadoes and hail, there is no wonder why Kansas possess toughness and grit. Laina and I pray for all impacted, and will do everything we can to help.

Being on the combine today took me back to a wonderful childhood. My dad's parents had a dairy while my mom's parents were more typical diverse Kansas farmers. They had about 160 acres of wheat along with alfalfa, grain sorghum and about 60 acres of pasture for a herd of Hereford.  My memories of wheat harvest include my uncle driving the wheat truck to the co-op elevator in Burns and getting a different bottle of Crush pop with each visit. This was the first time I ever had anything but Coca-Cola or Pepsi and my favorites quickly became strawberry and grape.   As I grew up and became old enough to drive the wheat truck or the tractors, I remember my grandma bringing shakes to the field on hot summer afternoons - made with vanilla ice cream and strawberry crush pop.  I also remember losing a wheat crop three days before harvest from a hailstorm and watching another wheat crop fail due to too much rain and not being able to get in the fields.  Those years remind me why my grandpa was so diligent about watching the weather report every night at 10:20 p.m.  My life seems a bit surreal this weekend: my close friend being nearly mortally shot just three days ago, playing in a baseball game that has become a congressional tradition, and riding on a combine yesterday outside Hoisington in a wheat field that I've used for pheasant hunts over the years.  Thanks to the Stoskopf family, Dean and Mary Anne, Julia and Josh, for letting me tag along today and relive some of those memories.  Wheat prices are at record lows but the yields look promising. It will be another very very tough year for agriculture. The experience only reinforces the importance of opening up new markets and trade opportunities and writing a strong farm bill.   I wish all of the farm families a safe and prosperous wheat harvest. Thank you for all you do for our great nation

The young people covered by DACA are not just a statistic on a DHS report. These are friends of my children, brothers and sisters of babies I’ve delivered, and members of my community. They didn’t put themselves in this position, and my heart goes out to them.  The United States is in this position due to the unilateral approach the previous administration took toward enacting DACA. It is because of that one-sided approach that we now have uncertainty and inconsistency throughout the entire immigration system. Consistency should be the hallmark of American governance.  Our resources, especially as they pertain to deportation, must remain focused on getting rid of bad people who present a danger to the American citizen – not a young person who is here simply due to circumstance. To date, 787,000 young people have legally registered with the U.S. government, and showed their willingness to follow our laws. We cannot allow that information to now be used against them in reverse order.  We are having these conversations now in Congress. Just a month ago, a Democrat colleague of mine and I got a bipartisan group of freshmen Members of Congress in a room to discuss what we can do to move forward on bipartisan, thoughtful solutions to the crises many communities and families are now facing.  Congress must use legal, legislative avenues to figure out how to help these young people, so long as they follow our laws. My priorities on this issue have always been, and will remain, to secure the border and help develop a workable visa for our farmers and producers back home. We must do right by them, by these young people and the safety of the American public.

I could not be more excited for this once-in-a-generation opportunity to truly reform our tax system.  Since 1986, the American people have not seen a meaningful update in federal tax policy. They have been asking for it for decades, and today, we've taken a huge step forward in delivering that promise.  More than anything else, the most common complaint I hear about the existing tax system is it's complexity. With this in mind, we aim to make it possible to file your taxes on a postcard. This simpler, quicker and easier system will give working and middle class Kansans the same access to the tax code as someone who has hired teams of accountants and lawyers to seek out every loophole.  These aren't just abstract changes for those who don't need it. Ideas like repealing the death tax, and allowing the first $12,000 of income for individuals and $24,000 for couples to be tax-free, and married couples to keep the first $24,000, are tangible ways that this reform will allow more money to stay in your pocket.  This fairer, simpler system will be a huge relief for the working and middle class. Gone are the days of a 75,000-page tax code full of favors and loopholes for the most powerful, wealthy and well-connected. This reform is overdue, and why many of my colleagues and I came to this body - to bring real-world, commonsense reform for our generation, for our kids, and for our grandkids. ICYMI: This week, the House passed Micah's Law, or the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act.  Science tells us that children in the womb can feel pain at or before 20 weeks. The United States is one of only seven countries worldwide who allow elective abortions after 20 weeks, and a majority of Americans want to see this changed.  As I said on the Floor this week, I've delivered some 5,000 babies, and worked closely with both mother and child to ensure a safe, healthy delivery.   In that time, I could give countless examples of a little girl at 16 or less weeks who stirred when she heard the voice of her brother or sister, mom or dad. At around that same time, she will often move, and respond to touch.  How or why, in my hospital, we would be working to preserve the life of that little girl, while in another facility, they are decapitating, and delivering her limb by limb, is a gross and cruel misuse of medical training. A violation of her life full of God-given potential.  I urge my colleagues in the Senate to act quickly, and get this bill on the President's desk. This week, I took to the house floor to condemn recent revelations of sexual harassment and the treatment of women on Capitol Hill. Throughout my career as a Doctor, I have spent decades working alongside female doctors, nurses and patients who were far too often put in inappropriate and sometimes downright dangerous situations because of their gender in the workplace or even at home. I am deeply concerned to hear that not only were these incidents uncovered on Capitol Hill, but that taxpayer funds were used to silence victims and defend the perpetrators. This is downright wrong – and the system must be fixed. Moving forward, it will remain a matter of upmost importance to my office to dedicate as much time and resources necessary to ensure that this type of behavior does not take place. From top-to-bottom, all members of my staff have taken a mandatory and comprehensive sexual harassment training course designed to ensure proper workplace conduct and performance; and what exactly to do if a problem arises.   Speaker Ryan and House Leadership has strongly urged all of my colleagues in Congress take similar steps to protect their staff and preserve a positive, safe and productive work environment.

As our Kansas farmers continue to face decade-low grain prices, we must ensure that federal policy encourages new markets for grain and related products. I would especially like to thank Administrator Pruitt and his staff for moving this approval process to the next step. I look forward to seeing the positive impact this pathway will have in the Kansas First District.

Today my son, Cal, and I helped serve lunch at the Hungry Heart Kitchen, which is part of the Dream Center in Great Bend. With no support from the federal or state government, the staff at the Dream Center run one of the most efficient homeless shelters and drug rehabilitation programs I’ve seen. The faith-based recovery program requires participants to be involved in some type of work program either at the Dream Center or in the community. In return employers in Great Bend open their businesses to these individuals who need a second chance and support on their path to success.   As a physician, I truly believe that long-term success in a rehabilitation program requires a spiritual component, a faith in God and hope for all. The local ownership and community-wide investment in the Dream Center has allowed hundreds of people to regain employment, housing and a drug-free life.
And just like that, in the blink of an eye my 4-month-old grandson, Weston, is standing on his own! He will be running around like his big brother ROW in no time.
